To put that into perspective.
Think of earth. Pretty big, right? No. Think of our entire solar system. Huge, right? Still no. Now think of our ENTIRE galaxy, ALL OF THE MILKYWAY, that's only 3 lightyears, from one end to the other. Three. Light. Years. Across.
Now think of 10 times that length. Multiply again. Again. Keep going, 10 times. You go 30, 300, 3,000, 30,000, 300,000, 3,000,000, 30,000,000, 300,000,00, then another ten times, 3 BILLION lightyears.
Now multiply by 3. That's how far away that is from us. For light there to reach us here now, 13.4 billion years old universe at the moment... that's been traveling for almost 3 quarters of that time. Almost 3/4 of the age of the universe itself.

The future will hold a world that again is 'dark'. Although it will only be dark if you want it to be.
Instead of lighting the entire landscape all you need is tiny projectors that shine directly onto the Retina in order to project an overlay of the local terrain that you can use to navigate your way around. The amount of electricity required to light a city in this way for all the people who need it would be a tiny fraction of what is used now. Pedestrians and drivers can 'see' everything, even better than nighttime illumination is currently, yet the world is actually dark when those projectors are turned off. As a bonus during the day the Eye-Projectors are used to provide overlays for Social and Locational information, POI's, Alerts & Alarms, etc. Someone might ask 'what happens if the projectors quit working at night?' to which I would respond with "That's a good reason to waste GigaWatt Hours of electricity to light the entire world? So there you have it the brightest thing in the universe is actually a catastrophic electromagnetically enhanced explosion of deadly radiation.

See if you were to hold up a 100 watt light bulb in front of your face it would be well.. brighter than the sun, but that’s not fair. Well if you were to put the light bulb and sun at the same distance away from you the sun would be a septillion times brighter that’s 4 illions after 1 trillion. Well in this case the brightest known thing is so to say the R136a1 now, this nuclear fueled beast is 256 times more massive than our sun, it’s the biggest and brightest known sun in the universe. Now remember that lower absolute magnitudes are brighter, R136a1 isn’t 4.8 like our sun but instead it’s negative 12.6 which means it’s 8.7 million times brighter than our sun, but R136a1 isn’t the brightest thing out there. When giant stars die it explodes violently and causes what is known as a super-nova or hyper-nova. Now, supernovas can eject terrifying flashes of radiation known as gamma ray bursts, arguably the brightest electromagnetic events in the universe. A typical gamma ray burst releases as much energy in a few seconds as our sun would release altogether in its entire 10 billion year lifetime. So there you have it the brightest thing in the universe is actually a catastrophic electromagnetically enhanced explosion of deadly radiation.

It’s crazy to me that something that I’m looking at, something that I can see with my own two eyes, doesn’t technically exist. Yes, it once existed and that’s what I’m looking at, the time that the object (in this case a quasar) existed, I can see it. However, relative to the time of today, that quasar doesn’t exist anymore.
Something that I can *see*, something that I am looking at with my own two eyes, isn’t technically there.
It’s crazy to me that, technically speaking , the whole universe could disappear, (The whole universe that is 1,000 light years away and more), and we wouldn’t even know it until 1,000 years from now. It would take us, 1,000 years to realize that the universe is gone.

That terrifies me, but it also puts into perspective how big our universe really is. Even as someone who loves space and like to learn new random facts about and is able to kind of understand how big certain things are, It’s still impossible to really grasp how phenomenally big the universe is.

But a question that I have, is that since we are looking at something that happened billions of years ago, are we looking into the past, technically speaking. Are our eyes technically looking back into time? That’s a really cool concept.

how to pronounce "yinyang"
1, It doesn't pronounce as a phrase, actually it is pronounced as two phrases, "yin" and "yang"
2, the word "Yin" is pronounced like "yeen", or "seen" with a silent "s"
3, "Yang" is pronounced exactly the same as "young"
4, The pitch of the Chinese word doesn't change no matter which sentence it is in. When pronouncing "Yin", keep a constant pitch like singing a song or sth, and making it short. Try to pronounce "phycho", and keep the pitch of "phy" part. that's same pitch when you pronounce "Yin"
5, For the "Yang", start with a low pitch and gradually raise your pitch, and make it short. if you don't get it, say "could you please......." and the way you pronounce "you" in that sentence is the same pitch when you pronounce "yang"

I truly hate light pollution. I love stargazing, but here in Central Florida, especially near Tampa, there's just so much god damned light pollution here that you can't see a damn thing. Eg: while you can make out the major stars of Ursa Major, those of the "Big Dipper" particularly, that's about all you can see in the entire area the constellation spans. Sirius looks like a speck.
You can't even see stars like Alpha Ursae Minoris (α UMi, or Polaris), which is a bit annoying since many telescopes require you to be able to point your telescopes right at Polaris in order to "calibrate" them. Filters don't help you. It's horrible.
The worst part is many cities near here have ordinances regarding light pollution, which, clearly, don't do s**t.

Hey, Matthew Here. Your Eyes Are A Mirror. When You Look Into An Eye, A Small Tiny Version Of YourSelf Appears That Kind Of Looks Like A Doll Version Of YourSelf. It’s A Pupil Because When You Look Into It You See A Pupa, A Small Doll Version Of You. But What Is The Brightest Thing In The UniVerse. Apparent Magnitude, Commonly Used When StarGazing Refers To How Bright An Object Appears To Us, Say When Looking Up From Earth. It Depends On Earths Centric Factors, Like How Close The Object Is To Our Planet. Magnitudes Are Logarithmic And Arranged Like Golf, Where A Smaller Number Means A Greater Brightness. But Today I’m Looking For Absolute Magnitude, A Measure Of How Bright EveryThing All Over The UniVerse Near And Far Would Be If We Looked At Them At The Same . Absolute Magnitude Will Guide Us To The Most Blinding Light In The UniVerse IrreSpective To It Looking Faint On Earth. If You Placed A LightBulb 8 Centimetres, About 3 Inches, Away Your Eye, It Would Appear Brighter Than The Sun In The Sky. But That’s Not Fair, If You Place A LightBulb Next To The Sun, The Sun Would Be A Septillion Times Brighter Than The LightBulb. But If You Lined EveryThing Out There Giving Every Star And Cosmological Phenomenon A Fair Chance, The Sun’s Absolute Magnitude Would Be 4.8. Not Bad. But Check Out R136a1. This Nuclear Fuelled Beast Isn’t The Biggest Star In The Terms Of Volume But It’s 256 Times Massive than The Sun It’s The Most Massive Star And The Brightest. There are galaxies near the cosmic horizon we were able to see decades before we'd have good enough telescopes to see galaxies that far away, because we could see light reflected from a quasar that had dimmed a lot in terms of the light reaching us directly, but the light tens of thousands of years later reflected from those (nearby) stars were thousands of times brighter than the light probably emitted by those stars. Some of the really big quasars turn nearby stars, unless they're really massive and dense, into more akin to a mirror than a lightbulb.

On a not too unrelated note: I've heard that we (us humans) actually know more about space than we do about our own oceans. However, seeing as "space" is ever-growing and thus basically infinite, makes it somewhat difficult for me to believe that statement. When I take a stroll at the beach for about 10 minutes, I would probably see more of the ocean than I will ever see of space in my entire life, speaking percentage. I mean... I know the pond in my backyard pretty well, and comparing it to all the oceans on earth may probably be like comparing our blue(ish), little ball to our whole galaxy. And yet our galaxy is just one out of hundreds of billions out there! (or so I've read >_>)
So how can we possibly say we'd know more about something that's so unfathomably large, than about our own oceans? It's ridiculous, right?

Here's a few things i measured with my phone's photo sensor.

- Under my desk right now: 0 to 1 lx (still EASILY visible, btw, you could go 20 times dimmer and still be able to walk around no problem though looking for specific things in messy drawers with this light is a bit difficult).

- Ambient brightness hitting me right now, light from a 34" screen at 25% brightness (mostly white image - youtube comment interface) and a 4w led indirect light behind the screen: 4 lx

- Same scene with the monitor cranked up to 100%: 8 lx

- Same scene, but from my perspective looking towards the screen (at 25%): 68 lx

- Same scene, but from my perspective looking towards the screen (at 100%): 165 lx (this screen is fucking bright, i still use it at 25% even during the day with sunlight coming through the windows)

- Light sensor aimed towards ceiling bulb (fluorescent tube styled 34w led lights, about 240cm away): 228 lx

- moderately bright pocket led flashlight with the beam in maximum spread from 1 meter away: 658 lx

- same flashlight, same distance, focused beam: 11580 lx (ouch, no wonder this thing can light buildings 2 blocks away quite visibly, brighter than the spot from a 4mw red laser)

- in an open field in the early afternoon in a cloudy day, aimed towards the horizon: 14000 lx (already hard to keep eyes open due to brightness even with fully contracted pupils)

- Same as above, but aimed at the sky / clouds: 25000 lx

- Clear day, outside, aimed towards a random scene: exceeds the 27500 lx limit of the sensor, so no point testing anything brighter. much brighter than cloudy day, this is probably into the hundred thousands lx depending on where you aim.

- Towards the sun: into the tens of millions? possibly even billions. don't fucking look at the sun.

Vsauce, you missed the truly brightest thing of all. The death of a black hole. As Hawking radiation becomes more and more rapid and the black hole loses mass, its final moments release unimaginable amounts of energy. A black hole of 1 kg would have 8.41072E-17 s to live, and at that very moment would have an absolute brightness 930,497 times that of our sun. At 0.5 kg, it would have 1.05134E-17 s left to live, and would have an absolute brightness 3,721,990 times that of our sun. A black hole with 1 Planck mass would have 8.67192E-40 left to live, and would have an absolute brightness 1.96424E21 times that of the sun.

Sure, none of us will ever actually see a black hole die, but Hawking radiation is very well accepted at this point, and so it really did deserve a place on this list.

Regarding WR104, which is 7500 ly away:
If a supernova from WR 104 is isotropic, its destructive consequences for the biosphere on Earth are predicted to be negligible. If it happens to be highly anisotropic however, there is a risk that it might cause significant harm, in particular because it is generally assumed that the rotational axis of both stars are orientated in the same way as the binary system, with an estimated (but uncertain) 12 degrees inclination relative to Earth. Anisotropic supernovae concentrate their radiative emissions in jet-cones along their rotational axis, so this face-on alignment makes WR 104 potentially dangerous. According to the data about WR 104, both supernovae are expected to be anisotropic.Regarding a GRB from WR 104 specifically, only sketchy estimates have been published so far. To predict the potential consequences for life on Earth, a proper determination of the rotational axis inclination relative to Earth is considered the most vital issue in this regard. If a beam of high energy radiation from a nearby GRB hits Earth, model calculations shows that it can have destructive consequences for the ecosystems. The range of destruction depends on the magnitude and distance of the burst and on how much of the radiation beam hits. It is currently "highly unlikely" that a GRB from WR 104 will pose a danger to life on Earth.According to astronomer Peter Tuthill, in order to damage life on Earth, the Wolf-Rayet star would have to undergo an extraordinary string of events:

The Wolf-Rayet star would have to generate a GRB. Because GRBs are associated with galaxies with a low metallicity and haven't yet been observed in our Milky Way Galaxy, astronomers believe it unlikely that WR 104 will generate a GRB. Tuthill tentatively estimates the probability for any kind of GRB is around the level of one percent, but cautions more research is needed to be confident.
The rotational axis of the Wolf-Rayet star, would have to be pointed in the direction of our planet. The star's axis is estimated to be close to the axis of the binary orbit of WR 104. Observations of the spiral plume are consistent with an orbital pole angle of anywhere from 0 to 16 degrees relative to the Earth, but a spectrographic observation suggest a significantly larger and therefore less dangerous angle. Estimates of the "opening angle" of a GRB's arc currently range from 2 to 20 degrees. (Note: The "opening angle" is the total angular span of a GRB radiation beam, not the angular span from the axis to one side. Earth would therefore only be in the path of a GRB if the actual angle of the star's axis relative to Earth is less than half the opening angle.)
The GRB would have to reach far enough in order to damage life on Earth. The more narrow a GRB radiation beam is, the farther it will reach, but the less likely it is to hit Earth.

It's amazing how bright R136a1 really is. True, it isn't the largest star known by volume but having an absolute magnitude of -12.6 is really damn impressive for a star. The largest star by volume in the Universe (so far) is a red supergaint called UY Scuti. Located in the constellation Scutum, UY Scuti has an estimated average median radius of 1,708 R☉, meaning it is 5 billion times larger than our sun. Its approximately 9,500 ly (light years) away from Earth. If UY Scuti was placed at our Solar System its photosphere would nearly engulf the orbit of Jupiter, although the radius is still not known for certain.

Guys imagine time like this; Imagine it as a book, the cover of the book is the very beginning, the Big Bang. Skip a few pages and we are in the present. The point is is that the time, the past and future already happened. It was already written in that imaginative book. So if we were to time travel we are opening the book, we are coming out of the 3rd dimension. Outside of the book is the 4th, and if we were time travelling we are opening pages of the time book. If we "alter" something in the past we are making a new book, imagine that past  as pg 49 of the book, and halfway through that page we changed something. The new timeline of the book isn't the same book, it's another book we created from changing something in that page 49. Or we can call "alternate timeline".

Black holes are fictional only mathematical objects that do not exist in the real physical world. They are derived from the theory of general realtivity (GR) which represent one highly speculative mental experiment that do not rely on scientific facts. There are two fundamental problems that makes the theory of general relativity inadequate to the physical world and as a consequence useless for the real science
The first one is that the mathematical apparatus of this theory does not work with physical objects which have physical properties and limitations. Instead it works only with geometric objects without such properties and limitations on which can be applied arbitrary mathematical operations. But all physical objects have such properties and restrictions. They obey physical laws without exeption.
The second reason is that the order in the universe can not be defined without absolute references - absolutes that do not change with time and position in the physical world. These absolute references are needed to be defined the precisely tuned physycal laws, constant and fundamental force interactions that support the originally established order in the univwerse in the interest of life.

Hi Michael,

I might be interpreting this the wrong way, but please correct met if I'm wrong...
If 3c273 at 33 light-years away is as bright as our sun at 8 light-minutes away, then wouldn't it be 59 trillion times as bright?

Taking into account the decay of light over distance in a vacuum: I=P/(4πr²) , Where I is the intensity of the light, P being the power of the Isotropic radiator and r being the distance or radius.
33 light-years = 33 * 365.25 * 24 * 60 light-minutes = 17,356,680 light-minutes = 2,169,585 times as far as 8 light-minutes.
and 4 * π * 2,169,585² = 59,151,151,460,085.566273988347419024

Or is it the other way around and it is 4 trillion times as bright as our sun, being equally bright at 8.6 light-years away, as our sun at 8 light-minutes?
Calculation:
4,000,000,000,000/4/π = 318,309,886,183.79067153776752674503
√318,309,886,183.79067153776752674503 = 564,189.58354775628694807945156077
564,189.58354775628694807945156077 * 8 = 4,513,516.6683820502955846356124862 light-minutes
4,513,516.6683820502955846356124862 / 60 / 24 / 365.25 = 8.5814827522664276667135059937755 light-years

In Bali, there is a public Holiday, "Nyepi", that happens for one day every year.

The name "Nyepi" literally means "to be quiet", but we have to do more than that - We are all required to turn our lights and other electrical appliances off for the whole day.

Granted, there are of course people who break the rules, but during the last Nyepi day (which was last week!), the sky was absolutely gorgeous. Not as good as a total city-wide blackout, though.

This is a common misconception; light travels through wires. Let's say you connect a battery to a switch to a bulb. You flick the switch, and for some reason, it takes 5 seconds for the bulb to turn on. The speed of light didn't slow down. What slowed down was the speed of heat. The speed of light would be the time it takes for heat to transform into light.

You can still see a lot living in a big city. I live in Philadelphia, one of the brightest cities in the US, and have no problem finding all the classical planets. About 10 years ago I saw Mercury, Venus, the Moon, Mars, Saturn and Jupiter across the sky at the same time, something that will not happen again in my lifetime. I've seen Mir and the Shuttle dozens of times, but the easiest thing to see is the ISS. The Space Station is so large it reflects an enormous amount of the Sun's light, making it easy to find. Try web sites like Heavens Above to find out when to look for it from wherever you are.

Every universe is covered by seven layers — earth, water, fire, air, sky, the total energy and false ego — each ten times greater than the previous one. Srimad Bhagavatam (10:87:41): Because You are unlimited, neither the lords of heaven nor even You Yourself can ever reach the end of Your glories. For the first time in my life, as I breathed the freshest and cleanest air far away from civilisations, I just saw the most beautiful sky in my life. Stars were highly visible, pouring the dark night sky with heart-warming blue as I wondered when our species will get to explore what's outside there. I envy our generations far into the future.
EPIC CONCLUSION!!!!! THANK YOU

Hey Vsauce!

I was thinking about the Taijitu, because of its mention in your video, and was eager to share a few things I know about it. 

Background first: My father works with solar panels quite frequently and so I get a great deal of exposure to them through him. Most of this is "hand-me-down" knowledge from him, so I may have a few things mixed up, but this is factual information to the best of my knowledge.

Okay, here's the good stuff: Solar panels work best in direct sunlight, and as you know, the sun rises in a slightly different place on the horizon every day, then follows a slightly different path across the sky before setting. this is dependent on the time of year. (the earth's tilt relative to it's position around the sun) It is because of this that researchers have attempted to understand and create a system of solar panels which actively "seek out" the suns light, and make the panels faces angled in such a way that the light is as direct as possible. The solution was much simpler than previously thought, as well as having been waved around under our noses for thousands of years. 

The Taijitus dividing line, between the dark and light sections represents the sun's position every day of the year, the white section actually represents light- Day, while that black represents night. The equinoxes are shown at the apexes of each curve, and the Solstices are at the center and top/bottom of the Taijitu. 
Now, this is the part which I am not entirely sure on: The "Spots" in either section are there just as markers to the radii of each curve. I know that that much of it is true, (mathematically, it works out) but I do not know if there is an additional reason for the spots in either section.

I was hoping that you could do a follow up video on this, because you mentioned in your video that there is no know connection between the roman's Taijitu and the Chinese'. So this would count as that connection If I'm correct. They would not need to have traded or interacted, but just had astronomers dedicated to watching the sun's pattern across the sky for an entire year before they realized they were back where they started.

I hope you find this interesting! I would really love to see you do a video on it, and any other relevant information you can find, I would love to hear!

White holes are the opposite of black holes, they are objects of infinite density that spit out matter. These objects likely won't come into existence, if they an exists, until near the end of the universe when blackholes start dying. 

But, there is no actual evidence to suggest the existence of these objects, just that they are mathematically possible.

Wonderful explanation of a gravity driven standard model.

Out of curiousity, have you ever took a gander over at the ThunderboltsProject? I find it truly fascinating that the emergence of plasma cosmology has been able to make spot on predictions about new discoveries where the standard model seems to fail horribly. I have taken both theories with a grain of salt but cannot help but feel that the Electric Universe model is fast becoming to new champion of astronomy. My first introduction to it was through the documentary "The Electric Comet" by Wallace Thornhill and it revealed something to me that screamed truth through simplicity.

I am not trying to be a converter of any kind, but I do ask that you take a look at it at least to see how it may speak to you.

At the least you must wonder why organizations like NASA are continually baffled by new discoveries because they do not fit the standard model (ie "impossibilities" they state) yet somehow are in existence and observable. I believe the Deep Impact mission sent to Tempel 1 was a crutial turning point for the theory, considering that every prediction made by Wal Thornhill was correct and none of NASA's predictions came true. Also on the subject of black holes, if the theory of Hawking radiation is correct then a black hole in the last 'Planck second' of it's life should technically be the brightest thing in the universe.

For a black hole of the Planck mass, that being 2.17651 x 10^-8 kilograms, it should take 8.671 x 10^-40 seconds to evaporate (wikipedia), equating to a power output of 2.256 x 10^48 watts.

If the power of the sun is 3.839 x 10^26 watts and a quasar is 4 trillion times brighter, the quasar has a power output of 1.5356 x 10^39 watts, meaning that a black hole on the last Planck second of it's life is around 1.47 billion times brighter.

Science!﻿

A Supernova is not quite the same thing as a Hypernova. While it is known that a Supernova is a massive star exploding, releasing huge amounts of energy, as Hypernova is strange in its magnitude. A Hypernova doesn't just release a Gamma ray beam that can strip a planet of life or its protective layers gravely endangering life on that planet, But it releases a massive omnidirectional "flash" or "pulse" that is so big and so powerful it can wipe life from most or all of its home galaxy. It's HALO for real...

A Hypernova is strange in that the mass needed is so much larger than the largest Supernova so far observed that it should normally result in a black hole of some magnitude. But the Hypernova does not. As far as I know, it totally disintegrates the star in question. One theory is that it is a massive Matter Annihilation Reaction, Anti-matter explosion. It is still only a theory but is studied, in part, to help figure out how to make anti-matter in bulk quantities to use as fuel.

It is thought that the Milky Way has at least one Hypernova Candidate. The conditions to cause such an explosion are not clearly known, but it is known that these events involve much older stars and, so far, none of our stars are old enough and powerful enough to blow up that big.

Also on the subject of black holes, if the theory of Hawking radiation is correct then a black hole in the last 'Planck second' of it's life should technically be the brightest thing in the universe.

For a black hole of the Planck mass, that being 2.17651 x 10^-8 kilograms, it should take 8.671 x 10^-40 seconds to evaporate (wikipedia), equating to a power output of 2.256 x 10^48 watts.

If the power of the sun is 3.839 x 10^26 watts and a quasar is 4 trillion times brighter, the quasar has a power output of 1.5356 x 10^39 watts, meaning that a black hole on the last Planck second of it's life is around 1.47 billion times brighter.

Science!

Light getting weaker over distances can be calculated using the inverse square law. Pretty simple, if an object doubles it's distance away from you, the brightness is a quarter, if it gets 3 time further away it is 1/9th and so on. You can also calculate the distance a star is away by taking the measurements of how far it move across the night sky in 6 months; if it moves 1/3600th of a degree it is 1 parsec away. A parsec is a measure of distance, i think 1 light year. That's all i can remember from my astronomy GCSE 2 years ago!
Edit
Regarding dark matter, dark matter is a type of anti-gravity. It's existence has only be hypothesised due to the way our galaxys spiral arms spin. As the you track the galaxy further out the rotation speed SHOULD slow down, but instead its velocity/rotation rate is similar to the rotational rate of the centre of the galaxy. This is strong evidence that dark matter is acting as an repellant/anti-gravity against the arms of the galaxy and spinning them faster. :) TheMoreYouKnow
